rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:22
rsbNotes.text: 14:22 as they were eating. The sacramental meal of the new covenant is intrinsically related to and grows out of that of the old (note the parallelism with Ex. 24:9–11). Jesus takes two elements of the Passover meal, unleavened bread and wine, to express His new work of redemption. See “The Lord’s Supper” at 1 Cor. 11:23.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:24
rsbNotes.text:
14:24 my blood. In the original Passover the blood of the lamb protected the Israelites from death (Ex. 12:23, 30). The phrase “blood of the covenant” comes from Ex. 24:8, and recalls that biblical covenants are sealed in blood (Gen. 15:9–21; 17:9–14; Ex. 24:4–8).

poured out for many. Jesus is alluding to Is. 53:12 where the Servant of the Lord “poured out His soul to death” and “bore the sin of many.”

rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:25
rsbNotes.text:
14:25 I will not drink. Jesus is hereby predicting the imminence of His death.

drink it new. Jesus expresses His faith in God who will not abandon Him in death.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:26
rsbNotes.text: 14:26 sung a hymn. This mention of singing is a reference to the Passover liturgy. Jesus and His disciples sing Ps. 115–118, the traditional close of the meal.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:28
rsbNotes.text: 14:28 to Galilee. The angel at the tomb remembers this promise and alludes to Peter’s denial (16:7).

rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:30
rsbNotes.text: 14:30 before the rooster crows twice. For other examples of Jesus’ knowledge of future events, see note on v. 13. The seemingly specific reference could also be a poetic way of saying “before dawn.”

rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:33
rsbNotes.text:
14:33 Peter and James and John. See note 5:37.

troubled. This verb is unique to Mark, and each time expresses deep emotional distress (9:15; 16:5, 6).

rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:36
rsbNotes.text:
14:36 Abba. A colloquial Aramaic word for “father,” which expresses Jesus’ close relation with God the Father. Mark records the Semitic word (5:41; 7:34; 11:9; 14:45; 15:22, 34).

cup. See note 10:38.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:37
rsbNotes.text: 14:37 one hour. In spite of noble intentions (14:29, 31), Peter is incapable of one hour of true discipleship.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:38
rsbNotes.text: 14:38 Watch. This exhortation recalls the warning of 13:32–37 to watch and not fall asleep before the coming of the Son of Man. “Temptation” is the trap of Satan to cause God’s people (in this case the Twelve) to fall and, if possible, to bring to nothing the plan of redemption.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:43
rsbNotes.text: 14:43 crowd. Probably a force sent by the Sanhedrin since the three categories of members of that body are mentioned (v. 53; 8:31 note).

rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:44
rsbNotes.text: 14:44 kiss. A sign of respect that disciples showed to teachers. After eating from the same dish (v. 20 note) Judas now feigns submission and respect.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:48
rsbNotes.text: 14:48 as against a robber. The Greek can mean either “robber” or “insurrectionist,” but in view of the charges brought against Jesus at His trial (Luke 23:2), “insurrectionist” is better.

rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:49
rsbNotes.text: 14:49 let the Scriptures be fulfilled. See note 8:31. In view of v. 50, the passage Jesus had in mind may be Zech. 13:7 (see v. 27).

rsbNotes.title: Mark 14:51
rsbNotes.text: 14:51 young man. Some interpreters have suggested that in this cryptic detail, as in the mention of the linen garment (a sign of wealth), there might be a veiled reference to Mark himself, since he was from a well-to-do family in Jerusalem (Acts 12:12).
